author: Kendall Ashman
title: Homeland Security and Wilson County Sheriff‚Äôs Office educate parents about online risks
text:
WKRN articles Homeland Security and Wilson County Sheriff‚Äôs Office educate parents about online risks Kendall Ashman Thu, December 5, 2024 at 10:50 PM UTC 2 min read
WILSON COUNTY, Tenn. (WKRN) ‚Äî Enough is enough. That is the message the Wilson County Sheriff‚Äôs Office and Homeland Security are sharing with parents Thursday night. This comes after the sheriff‚Äôs office received reports of sextortion cases, as well as a handful of school threats made on social media this school year.
In September, the Wilson County Sheriff‚Äôs Office responded to one school threat after the other.
‚ÄúThe whole month of September there were 18 threats. Then I look at our stats last month and we had one,‚Äù said Scott Moore, Wilson County Sheriff‚Äôs Office Captain.
üìß Have breaking news come to you: Subscribe to News 2 email alerts ‚Üí
News 2 asked Captain Moore how many of the 18 threats in September were made on social media. ‚ÄúI would say at least three out of every four,‚Äù Moore said.
Advertisement Advertisement Advertisement It‚Äôs a trend seen here in Middle Tennessee and across the country.
In September, one Mt. Juliet middle school student was taken into custody after a school threat was spread on TikTok. At Barry Tatum Academy, a student was charged with threats of mass violence and two counts of false reports after a bomb threat was made.
‚ÄúWhenever we have a school threat, we utilize so many resources. It‚Äôs not just the SRO, it involves the detective division and Homeland Security,‚Äù Moore said.
In response, Homeland Security created an initiative called Project iGuardian to raise awareness about the risks for minors on social media and prevent them from falling victim to tactics used by online predators.
Advertisement Advertisement ‚ÄúOne of the things and we‚Äôve had cases here in Wilson County involving sextortion and it‚Äôs a real problem rising across the country,‚Äù Moore said.
‚è© Read today‚Äôs top stories on wkrn.com
On Thursday, the Wilson County Sheriff‚Äôs Office and Homeland Security want to start a conversation with parents so they can be more aware of online dangers.
‚ÄúAs parents at home we need to have talks with them and tell them this is why this is important and not be involved or start communication or send pictures like this it‚Äôs something we don‚Äôt preach enough,‚Äù Moore said.
The meeting is being held at the Wilson County Board of Education from 6-8 p.m.
